comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: Pitt and Margaret Streets no longer meet - this section is now called Curtin Place. NW corner, Google Street view - maps.google.com.au/maps?ie=UTF8&hq=&hnear=Sydney+... Just discernible on the front of the building is "FARMER AND COMPANY" and the date "1883"(?) on the top. A quick Trove search produced this SMH article from Saturday 5/4/1884 describing the "New Warehouse" in great detail - its height, iron girder construction, lifts, and those enormous plate-glass windows. trove.nla.gov.au/ndp/del/article/13560352 Perhaps this fine photo was taken to record a new showpiece building in 1884?

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content:
H O L D  T H E   P R E S S E S  !!

I was wrong again - it is NOT MARGARET St / Curtin Place and Pitt St corner.  The road dips there (and used to be called Little George St).

It is MARKET Street and Pitt Street NW corner.  See the SMH article above.

Also wrong on the State Records database.

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: The facade (or seven of the nine window width) is still there, part of Myers (?) . It is the pale building, the corner has been rebuilt using red brick on this Google Street View - maps.google.com.au/maps?ie=UTF8&hq=&hnear=Sydney+...

comment._content: The building on the left of the shot may have been there until the monorail was built in 1987.   I have something which I bought in the shop which was there,  just before it was demolished.

comment.author: 35672655@N00
comment._content: thats Victor House (Farmers Store) from 1882. The first highrise in Australia  to boast a lift using the "Otis" principal.(suspended cables).  It was tallest building in Sydney at 91ft high. Most of its facade is still extant.

comment.author: 86916510@N00
comment._content:
That isn't Myer! judging from the shadows, camera is pointing SW and looking at what is now  St George Bank. Myer would be across the road camera right.

You could argue that they are morning shadows but afternoon light has the softer look as pictured.

Beachcomberaustralia ! you are all over this site!  Love your input! thanks!

comment.author: 73199923@N00
comment._content: In 1923 Farmer & Co received Australia's first commercial broadcasting licence and broadcast as 2FC (Farmer & Co.) before being nationalised by the federal Postmaster-General's Department who outsourced program production to the Australian Broadcasting Company and introduced a listener licence fee per station and sealed all wireless sets to the chosen station. The 2FC studio and small antenna in this building per: "Radio Broadcasting Station 2FC 2FC began broadcasting on 5/12/1923. Farmer and Company Limited Broadcasting Service leased land from the corner of Edinburgh Road and Lyle Street (now part of Eastern Valley Way) to halfway to Sugarloaf Creek. Powered by 5,000 watts, it was 'the world's largest broadcasting station' (1923 Willoughby Municipal Council Annual Report). Two steel lattice towers 200 feet high and 600 feet apart supported a squirrel type cage aerial. The main operating room and staff quarters were directly below. The studios in Pitt Street were linked to Willoughby by landline. In 1929 the transmitter, by then out of date, was dismantled and moved to Homebush Bay." trove.nla.gov.au/ndp/del/printArticlePdf/16281742/5?print=n
